loans.name: Erikanjeru

texts.en: Erikanjeru is 62 years old, married with six children, and living in his own house in Fort Portal Uganda.  Strongly motivated to secure a sustainable income for his family, Erikanjeru has been farming for 20 years, and with the income generated he was able to educate most of his children. Now seeking business diversification, he is requesting a loan to to buy a motorcycle in order to enter the transportion sector.

loans.use: Buying a mortorcycle for transport business.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson, a member of Highrise Star group in Faulu Kenya, saves his money on a weekly basis and can easily access loans from Faulu Kenya because the group members guarantee each other's loans.  He joined the group as an entrepreneur who runs a retail shop and distributes bread.  Wilson opened his retail shop eight years ago and hopes to expand it into wholesale in the future.  He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes to add a stock of cereals to his shop.

loans.use: To add stock of cereals

loans.name: Moses Wethakhori

texts.en:
Moses Wethakhori A. is 38 years old. He is married to Salina Aregae, who is a housewife. They have three school-going children aged 19, 15, and 10 years old. Their residence is in Lodwar, Kenya. 

Moses operates a general store. He has been in this business for four years and earns a monthly profit of KES.20,000.

Moses learned about KADET LTD from a credit officer. He is applying for his third loan of KES. 80,000 from KADET LTD. He intends to buy three bags of rice, three bags of sugar, four boxes of cooking supplies and 12 crates of soda. He plans to invest the profits from this venture in a hide and skin business.

In the future, Moses wishes to become a big businessman. His deeper desire is to see his children realize their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, cooking supplies, and soda.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng S., 39, is married and resides with his wife in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. He is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 5 per day, while his wife is a farmer earning an income of USD 1 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 38 on other necessary expenses.

Heng is now requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new motorbike for family use. In the future, he would like to use any additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Anna Akuyuk

texts.en:
Anna Akuyuk E. is a woman of forty-eight years. She is married and the mother of four children. They live in Soweto in the outskirts of Lodwar Town, where her business is located. She operates a food stall where she sells cooked food, such as beans and rice. She has been in this business for two years and earns a monthly income of ten thousand shillings.

This will be Anna's first loan from KADET LTD. She plans to buy more food so that she can increase her inventory. With the income she will earn, she wants to expand the stall and have a bigger stall. In the future, she wants to be more financially stable .

loans.use: To buy more food for to sell

loans.name: Zainab's Group

texts.en:
Zainab, 51, lives in Okara, a small Pakistani city known for its agriculture industry. She resides in the small housing colony named Faisal Mehmood with her family in a two-room brick house. Zainab is a housewife, preferring to stay at home and and discharge her household responsibilities. She is also an expert in sewing clothes, earning family income by sewing for her neighboring clients.

Zainab is a mother of seven children: three sons and four daughters. Her elder son works in a Punjabi food restaurant, while her daughter also sews clothes. Five are at home, while two others are getting their education. Her husband, M. R., runs a shop in the market where he sells construction supplies to his regular customers and also to the building constructors.

Zainab has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her sewing business, which she has operated for over 10 years. With the loan, she will buy a new sewing machine which will help her work more efficiently and complete orders on time, as her current machine has become old and incapable of producing quality work. She is hopeful that an investment will earn her more profits.

Zainab is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit history and has faithfully attended all meetings.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Chem Y., 42, is widowed and resides in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. He buys and sells motorbikes, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 58 on other necessary expenses. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike to resell. In the future, he would like to use any additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to resell

loans.name: Trust In God Development Group - Kampala

texts.en:
38-year-old Robinah N. has been selling fruits, vegetables and soft drinks in Kireka, Kampala for the past 6 years. 

The happily married mother of two says she started this business because of the influence of one of her closest friends. Her friend persuaded her not to just sit at home. Her friend's reasoning was that Robinah could not bring value to her life by just being a housewife. 

Robinah, who comes across as a God-fearing, hard-working and affable lady, says her business profits are to the tune of 100,000 shillings per week. Robinah says that, with this loan, she is going to revamp her business. Robinah is affiliated with the Trust in God development group in Kampala.

loans.use: To renovate her business

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells groceries, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a logger, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 55 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Evana

texts.en: Evana is currently in a business of selling "kimbo", beer and "suko".  She is 35 years old, married to a farmer, and has 6 children, three of whom go to school.  She requested a loan to stock more kimbo, beer and suko to sell.  With extra profits, Evana hopes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: Stock more kimbo, beer and suko to sell.

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana is a talented lady who owns & operates a beauty salon in her home. She offers her service of makeup and facial treatments to her customers according to their demands. She is an expert in her work and has a good number of clients in her region. 
She is 34 years old and married, with 3 sons. Her husband's name is M. S..   He lives in the city of Karachi, where he has a business selling spare parts. The business brings in a good income every month. 
Farzana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her beauty salon business. With the loan, she will buy beauty products such as creams, face masks and hair gels and make-up items such as mascaras, eye shadows and lipsticks in bulk to provide better services to her customers. 
She is hopeful that through this loan investment her business will be improved and she will be able to manage the expenses of her home better. 
She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

loans.use: To buy beauty products and make-up items for beauty salon

loans.name: Samuel Muumbiati

texts.en:
Samuel Muumbiati M. is thirty-three years old. He is married to Josephine Andeso and together they are blessed with two children. They live in Langas in Eldoret Town. His wife, Josephine, works as a green grocer in the same area. 

Samuel is a fruit vendor in the Eldoret Town Centre. He has been in this business for three years and he earns a monthly income of eight thousand shillings.

This will be Samuel's first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the entire loan to buy fruit, like pawpaw and avocado. With the income that he will earn, he plans to expand his business further.

In the future, he hopes to raise his standard of living and buy his own land.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan P., 31, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a tailor, earning an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a member of the military, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 66 on food and USD 55 on other necessary expenses. Phan is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more fabrics to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to expand the business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia V. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 50 years old. Lucia is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Lucia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Lucia wishes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

Lucia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rael

texts.en: Rael is a married lady with one child.  She owns a stall in Kibera slums where she mainly sells  shoes.  She runs a business with one employee.  She has been running the business for three years.  She joined Faulu Kenya under the Karina group.  In the group, she is able to access loans from Faulu Kenya because the members guarantee each others loans.  She has requested a loan for 20,000 Kes to add stock of second-hand shoes.

loans.use: To add stock of second-hand shoes

loans.name: Luciga

texts.en:
Luciga C. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 42 years old. Luciga is married and has 3 children aged 22, 20, and 15. To make a living, Luciga owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Luciga sells soft drinks and other products.

Luciga joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luciga has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Luciga is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia M. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 53 years old. Lucresia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lucresia owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lucresia also helps her husband maintain their rice farm.

Lucresia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucresia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lucresia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her clothes-selling business. She buys clothes from Faisalabad which is known for its textile industry and sells them in her local city. She comes from Okara, a small city in Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Faisal Mahmood for the past 8 years. Her husband works abroad. 

Azra has given birth to 3 children. Her eldest daughter is in class one while the others are too young to attend school. As her husband is abroad, all the household responsibilities fall on her shoulders. She is managing these responsibilities with great courage and playing her role as a mother and a housewife very well. 

She is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for her business and she will be able to make more profits due to bulk purchasing that will allow her to offer her customers more variety. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 

Note: In the photo the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Azra.

loans.use: To buy clothes for business

loans.name: Radnaa

texts.en:
Radnaa is 61 years old and lives with her husband, daughter, grandchild and son-in-law in an apartment in the Songino-Hairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter is on her maternity leave while her daughter's husband works as a private businessman. Her husband is retired. 

Radnaa operates a sausage and pickled vegetable trading business out of a rented stall at a Dragon trade center. She used to sell her products at Narantuul, the largest and main market in the city, but she has moved to her current business location where she attracts many customers.

For the future, Radnaa plans to expand her business by increasing her product line and enlarging her stall. She is a very clever and business-minded person and says, "My business is good, with stable operation and reasonable earnings. Further on, I plan to try operating another business." Radnaa is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase grocery products for the upcoming holidays.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina T. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 51 years old. Ludivina is married and has two children aged 28 and 18. She manages a small piggery in her backyard. She grows the pigs for breeding and then sells the pigs to the market. Ludivina wishes for her business to be stable.

Ludivina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ludivina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ludivina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional piglets and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 52 years old. Magdalena is married. To make a living, Magdalena owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Magdalena also retails gasoline. She says it is very helpful to motorists because the next gas station is quite far.

Magdalena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama M. makes palm oil at Abura for resale.  Ama has been through junior high school.  She is a widow taking care of ten dependents. She has been in this business for three years. She responsibly provides the basic needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more palm fruit to process into oil for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her dependents.

loans.use: to buy more palm fruit to process into oil for sale

loans.name: Maximiana

texts.en:
Maximiana, 39 years old, is a married woman from the town of Trinidad. She is engaged in fishing. She helps her husband operate their fishing boat to catch assorted fish. Maximiana then sells her husband's catch at the market. Maximiana's husband also uses their motorcycle for business. He transports people around their community and this gives them daily income. 

Maximiana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maximiana is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the first loan taken out by Maximiana from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Hameedan's Group

texts.en:
Hameedan comes from Okara which is a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its dairy industry. She has been living there in a small housing colony called Faisal Mehmood for the past 25 years. Her house contains 2 rooms and is made of bricks. 

She is 44 years old, married to M. S., and has 3 sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is a daily wage laborer while her 2nd son has a furniture-making business. Her youngest son is in kindergarten while her daughter is only 3 years old. 

Her husband operates a four-wheeled cart with which he sells seasonal fruit by visiting different areas. He sells fresh, quality fruit to his customers and for that reason, his sales are good every day. 

Hameedan helps her husband financially by weaving carpets. She receives orders from different shops and factories and completes the orders on time to earn an income. She has been doing this business for over 15 years. The earned income allows her to manage the financial situation of her family.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her business. With the loan, she will buy items such as thread and weaving tools which will help her finishing larger orders on time and make better income. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Hameedan.

loans.use: To buy thread and weaving tools for carpet weaving business

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun V., 28, is married and resides with her husband and one child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells palm fruit, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells palm sugar, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 43 on other necessary expenses. 

V. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Nesa

texts.en:
Thirty-eight-year-old Nesa P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has five children. Her eldest child is 17 years old, while the youngest is only 6. Nesa is engaged in rice farming. She and her husband make sure their rice crops are healthy and that the farm is free of weeds and pests. Nesa also runs a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells various kinds of products. Nesa wishes to be successful in life.

Nesa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nesa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Nesa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Efua Kwame

texts.en:
Efua Kwame B. is married and has eight dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She buys and resells mortars and pestles for sale. She also sells sugar, which she has been doing for 10 years. 

Efua uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Efua will use the loan to purchase more mortars and pestles for resale. Efua plans to reinvest back into her business the new profits from her expanded business.

In the picture is Efua with a mortar. This type of mortar is what Ghanaians pound palm fruits with when preparing palm-nut soup.

loans.use: To purchase more mortars and pestles for resale

loans.name: Pom

texts.en:
Pom N., 42, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She sells fish, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband raises pigs, earning an income of $1 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Each month, the family has to spend $66 on food and $43 on other necessary expenses. N. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase pig food. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en:
Presentacion G. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 52 years old. Presentacion is married. To make a living, Presentacion operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from catching and selling assorted fish to the market. 

Presentacion joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Presentacion has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Presentacion is requesting a new loan of 9,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua K. is married. She has received a junior-high education. She makes rice into porridge and serves it with milk and bread in Abura. She has been selling rice porridge for three years. 

She is asking to use the loan to expand her business by buying more rice, milk and bread to cook and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to buy land.

loans.use: To buy more rice, milk and bread to cook and sell

loans.name: Gabina

texts.en:
Gabina is from the town of Trinidad. Gabina is married and has five children. Her eldest child is 37 years old and the youngest is 19. To make a living, Gabina runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gabina says she wishes that her children will be successful.

Gabina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gabina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Gabina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Imelda Akiru

texts.en:
Imelda Akiru M. is a thirty-four-year-old married woman who has three children. Her husband is a business man in Lodwar.

Imelda has two businesess in Lodwar,  a salon which also has a boutique inside it. She has been in these business for ten years and earns a monthly income of thirteen thousand shillings.

With her loan from KADET LTD, Imelda plans to buy more clothes for the boutique so that she can sell them to customers who come to her salon. 

She plans to use her income to increase her clothing inventory. In the future, she would like to be finacially stable so that she can support her family comfortably.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Oktay

texts.ru:
Oktay N. rodilsya v 1954 qodu. On jenat i imeyet 3 detey. Oktay yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli regiona i seychas projivayet v qorode Baku vmeste  lubimoy jenoy i detmi.
Oktay uje qod kak  rabotayet taxistom, ranshe on chinil mashini no spustya vremya on reshil stat taxistom, Oktay ochen polubil svoyu novuyu rabotu. Eto uje vtoraya ssuda Oktaya on ochen blagodaren lenderam i Kive za pervuyu ssudu. 
Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya mashini.
texts.en: Oktay N. was born in 1954. He is married and has three children. He is an Internally Displaced Person, a refugee from the Fuzuli Region now living in the city of Baku together with his beloved wife and children. It has been a year since  Oktay started working as a taxi driver. He used to be an auto mechanic, but later he decided to become a taxi driver. He grew to really like his new line of work. This is Oktay’s second loan; he is very grateful to Kiva lenders for his first loan. At present he needs 2000 AZN to purchase spare parts for his car.

loans.use: Purchasing spare auto parts

loans.name: Liduena

texts.en:
Liduena M. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 54 years old. Liduena is married and has three children. To make a living, Liduena raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale.

Liduena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liduena has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Liduena is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa B. is divorced. Adjoa sells drinks and bags of charcoal in Abura, which she has been doing for some time now. Adjoa wants to expand her business. She is therefore requesting to use the loan to buy additional bags of charcoal to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S., 41, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. He is a farmer, earning an income of $1 per day. His wife is employed at the factory, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.

Each month, the family has to spend $50 on food and $85 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase wood to build a chicken cage to raise chickens. In the future, he would like to use any additional income to repair his house. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a chicken cage to raise chickens

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa D. is married to a farmer and has eight dependants. She has received a junior high education.  Adjoa prepares Fante kenkey at Abura for sale. Adjoa assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her children. Adjoa will use the loan to buy more maize to cook to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to further her children’s education.  In this picture, Adjoa has in her hand a sample of the Fante kenkey. In the pan is the maize she uses for the kenkey.

loans.use: To buy more maize to cook kenkey to expand her business

loans.name: James Gikundi

texts.en:
James Gikundi R. is a man of 31 years married to Pauline Keinda, who sells green vegetables. Together, they have three children. They live in Lodwar town, where James does his tailoring business. He has been in this business for 20 years now and gets a monthly income of 13,500 Kenyan shilling (KES).

This will be James' fourth loan from KADET LTD; he has been repaying all other loans successfully. With this loan, he plans to buy materials and make clothes so that he can sell the clothes. 

With the income he is going to get, he plans to open another tailoring shop in Lodwar town. In the future, James wants to be financially stable and to support his family by providing for their every basic need.

loans.use: To buy materials for making clothes

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en: Shabana lives in Okara, which is a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She lives there in the area of Kirpa ram with her family in a two-room brick house. She moved here four years ago. She is 35 years old and married to M. W. who works in a government organization on a monthly wage. After his day job, he runs a butcher shop in the community where he sells chicken meat to his customers. People prefer buying meat from him because of his good quality and freshness. Shabana supports her family by doing sewing work. She takes orders from her neighbors and earns a good income by completing them on time. She uses her income to pay off the utility bills. Shabana is the mother of two children: a three-year-old daughter and a two-year-old son. They need full attention from her and Shabana tries her best to fulfill her duties. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy chickens in bulk and increase his sales. Shabana is very hopeful that her husband’s business will expand further after the loan investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. With the previous loan, she established good credit and never missed any meeting. Note: “In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shabana”.

loans.use: To buy chickens in bulk

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa N. cooks food for sale at Abura.  She has been through junior high school.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. She has been cooking rice for sale for five years now. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy food items to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a cafeteria.

loans.use: To buy food items to expand her business

loans.name: Marcellah Longacha

texts.en:
Marcellah Longacha K. is a woman of 26 years, married and the mother of four children. Her husband is a businessman in Lodwar. She also has a business selling mobile phones and accessories in Lodwar Town. She has been in this business for two years now and makes a monthly income of 10,000 shillings.

This will be Marcellah's first loan from KADET and she plans to use the entire loan to buy different types of mobile phones and accessories for resale. With the income she makes, she wants to expand her business by buying more phones for resale. In the future she would like to be financially stable and support her family.

loans.use: To add stock, e.g., different types of mobile phones and accessories for resale

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren, age 35, lives with her husband and two daughters in a traditional housing tent called a ger in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She has been living with her family at their permanent address for the past 11 years. Her husband provides transportation with his own car and her two daughters both attend a local school. Since 1998, she has been operating a meat trading business, purchasing meat at wholesale prices. She has a rented stall in the biggest market of the province. After many years owning this business, her working capital has reached a level of 600,000 MNT and her monthly sales income exceeds 2,000,000 MNT. She purchases a large amount of meat when prices for such products are cheap and preserves it for sale in the winter when it is in high demand. She is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more meat to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua B. is divorced and has nine dependents. Ekua makes palm oil in Abura for sale. Ekua wants to produce in larger quantities, so she is asking to use the loan to purchase additional palm fruits to process for resale. The income she makes is used to provide for the basic needs of the family. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional palm fruits to process for resale

loans.name: Zinunula Community Bank, Nansana - Kampala Group

texts.en: N. Efrance, age 60, is a happily married mother of five who has been in dairy farming in Natete-Kampala for the past 20 years. She also has a side business selling firewood and water from which she ekes out additional profits. Before taking root in any of the aforementioned businesses, she was bearing a hand in a charcoal sales business, which she has since dispensed with. In the future, Efrance says she wants to expand her business horizons, and principally she is looking at constructing her own rental structures. For now, she says her focus is mainly on improving her current businesses. Weekly, this business generates 30,000 shillings for her. She says, with this loan, she is going to buy more firewood to resell. Efrance belongs to Zinunula Community Bank, Nansana - Kampala.

loans.use: To purchase firewood to resell

loans.name: Mariam Waithira

texts.en:
Mariam Waithira K. is a single woman of forty eight years old, with two children, they live in Lodwar town where she does her cloth selling business, she has been in this business for ten years now and gets a monthly income of thirteen thousand five hundred shillings.


This will be Mariam's first loan from KADET and she plans to use the entire loan to purchase new stock of clothes for her business, with the income she will get she wants to diversify her business by venturing into hotel business. 


In furute she wants to support her family by providing them with basic needs like food, clothing, shelter and education.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama M. sells kenkey (fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves) and bags of charcoal in Abura. She is a widow responsible for six dependents. She provides for the needs of her dependents with the income she makes from her sales. 

Her loan will be used to acquire extra bags of charcoal for resale. She anticipates reinvesting the new profit.

loans.use: To acquire extra bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Julia Nyambura

texts.en:
Julia Nyambura N. is a single young woman of twenty three years, she lives with her mother whom she supports financially, they live in Lodwar town where she runs her business of selling used clothes, she has been in this business for three years now and gets a monthly income of thirteen thousand shillings.


This will be Julia's first loan from KADET LTD, she plans to use the entire loan to add more stock to her business, with the income she is going to get the plans to plough back to her business and open another shop for selling used clothes. In future she wants to be a self sustained lady and have a great life.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anis' Group

texts.en:
Anis is a talented lady. She sews clothes as a business at her home to share the financial burden of her family. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients and earns well by completing them on time. In addition to her business, she is also a very good housewife and does her household responsibilities very well. 

She has given birth to two sons. Her elder son lives abroad, while her younger son is married and works in a government organization for a monthly wage. After his day job, he operates a spare-parts shop through which he offers spare parts for different vehicles to his clients. 

Anis has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially support her younger son, who wants to improve his business by purchasing spare parts. The additional spare parts will help him to sell to those clients who have sought parts that he couldn’t provide for them due to non-availability, with the result that he will make them his permanent customers and increase his income as well.
 
Anis is hopeful that through the loan investment, her son will be able to get more profits from his business and will improve its financial condition. She is regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.
 
She belongs to Okara, which is a small city of Pakistan known for its agricultural industry. She lives there in the area of Kirpa ram with her family in a two-room brick house.  

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book called the Asasah Passbook is Anis.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Namig

texts.ru:
Namig H. rodilsya v 1971 qodu. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom, on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so sovyey semyoy. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey, odin iz kotorix uhcitsya v kolledje a druqoy v shkole. On ochen lubit svoyu jenu i detey i svoyu rabotu.
Namig uje 9 let kak zanimayetsya skotovodtvom, etomu biznessu on nauchislya u svoyeqo starsheqo brata. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa. Namig prodayot u sebya doma  yogurt i kefir kotoriy delayet sam i moloko, na yeqo produkti imeyetsya bolshoy spros.
texts.en:
Namig Hadiyev was born in 1971. He is an Internally Displaced Person, a refugee from the town of Fuzuli, now living in the Region on Fuzuli together with his family. He is married and has two children, one of whom is a college student and the other is in secondary school. Hamig loves his wife and children and his work.


Namig has been raising cattle for nine years. He learned this work from his older brother. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy a cow and expand his business. Namig sells milk, homemade yougurt and kefir out of his home. His milk products are in big demand.

loans.use: Purchasing a cow

loans.name: Wcsl Pri Mabonkani Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the WCSL primary School, Mabonkani village, near Makeni. WCSL Primary School was founded in 1972 by the Weslyan Mission to help educate the children of Mabonkani village. Currently, the school is staffed with 14 teachers and has about 400 pupils. 

This is the first loan that this school has applied for from Kiva lenders. Mrs. Agnes Y. S. is their leader and head mistress at the school. The 55-year-old Agnes was born in Mabonkani village and has been in the teaching profession for 31 years. She has three children: one in primary school, one in secondary school and one in college. Mrs. S. has requested this loan in order to pay school/college fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school/college fees for her children

loans.name: Abdulatif

texts.en:
K. Abdulatif is in the livestock business. He breeds livestock, with which he provides sustenance for his humble home. Abdulatif is married and has 5 children. It is important to note that since he started his business, he has acquired an abundance of experience due to his great dedication and the knowledge he has acquired from breeding his animals. The reason that Abdulatif looks for support from IMON International is that he needs to purchase livestock so he may sell it and continue with his arduous work with cattle in this sector.     


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of cattle in order to expand the business.

loans.name: Khaliyar

texts.en:
H. Khaliyar is married father who has 4 children. Khaliyar has been a farmer for the last 11 years. Farming is a passion to him. He practices both dairy farming and mixed crop farming. He says he has chosen farming as a career because the produce he produces in his farm has a ready market. His challenge at the moment is that he is not fully utilizing his whole piece of land because he used up all the proceeds form his last harvest to pay his children's school fees. So, he was not able to buy the seeds and fertilizers needed to plant his whole land. Khaliyar is requesting for a loan of $1500 USD to be able to purchase the resources needed to plough the whole farm for the next planting season. He will purchase assorted fertilizer stock and seeds.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Ergashkhon's Group

texts.en:
Ergashkhon B., 52, was selected as a leader of this group by collective voting of all members. Throughout all these years she has proven that she can be relied upon,  thanks to her responsibility and compassion towards others. Ergashkhon is in close relationship with all the members of the group, so she hopes this loan will help each one of them to improve their living standards. 

Ergashkhon is a proud mother of a nineteen-year-old girl and her husband is a welder. Ergashkhon has always had an incredible faith in a key role of education in the future of Kyrgyzstan. With beliefs to fulfill this mission, she got a degree in teaching. Most of her life she has spent teaching kids in elementary and high schools. Fourteen years ago, she and her husband had financia hard times, so it was time to look for an additional souce for the family budget. The family bought two heads of livestock for fattening and reselling. Their business turned out successfully and soon they had a small flock. Day by day the expenses for cattle breeding are getting higher, so it grows harder to cover all the costs and still generate enough profit. Ergashkhon would be very thankful to receive this loan, because she plans to buy more heads of livestock for reselling. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Saidodkhom

texts.en:
Saidodkhom is married and has 4 children. His family lives in Kumsangir, Tajikistan. Saidodkhom is a small entrepreneur and an owner of a grocery store, selling food items in his home town. His store is well known in his community for the variety of inventory and his reasonably priced, quality goods. Saidodkhom has managed to stay afloat for 5 years. He admits that it has been partly possible due to the consistent demand for the type of merchandise he offers for sale. 

Saidodkhom is seeking a loan of $3000 USD to purchase additional merchandise and to increase his turnover capital. He has an enterprising spirit and is always full of ideas on how to improve his business and make it even more profitable. Saidodkhom has a good credit history, which secures prompt repayment of the current loan.

loans.use: Purchasing more food for increasing the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase potato seeds.

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir is married with two sons: 20-year-old Dennis and 12-year-old Artyom. Vladimir lives in Kamenka, which is a predominantly agricultural region of Ukraine. He grows early spring vegetables in his greenhouses for further sale. Vladimir owns two greenhouses and a swinery. He has been working in the sphere of farming for 22 years. He has already invested about 150,000 Grivnyas in this enterprise. 

Vladimir is seeking a 15,000 Grivnya loan to purchase seeds and polyethylene film. He has recently purchased additional land and constructed another swine barn there. Currently, Vladimir is planning to finish building two more greenhouses for tomatoes at the property he owns. One of his personal goals is to help his children through college and give them a good start in life.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and polyethylene film

loans.name: Abdumavlon

texts.en: Abdumavlon is married with two children. He owns a minivan and offers transportation services in the city. He understands his role as the head and provider for his family, and is ready to work 24/7 to provide for the needs of his loved ones. He has been faithfully working in this business for eight years. Abdumavlon has found his niche in this business. Today, it’s a lot harder to start your own business as a public van driver. Currently, Abdumavlon’s net profit is about $500 a month. An economical diesel engine in his vehicle helps him reduce his operating costs and adds to his bottom line. Loans that Abdumavlon has received from IMON International have helped to promote stability and growth in his business. Abdumavlon is asking for a loan of 7,000 Somoni to purchase necessary car parts to fix his minivan. He understands the effort and commitment it takes to be a private entrepreneur and is willing to work hard in his business to be able to support his family, which is the first priority in his life. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for maintenance of his minivan

loans.name: Shailkan's Group

texts.en: Shailkan U., 48, is a leader of this group whose members live in a small, coal-mining town called Tashkomur. She is very keen to develop herself and her business of raising and reselling goats. Shailkan is very driven to secure her livelihood and advance her family’s social standing so that her children have a firm base to stand on. Shailkan’s permanent occupation is cookery. She is a chief cook for a local private-enterprise firm, while her husband is a security worker. As her children grow, the oldest of whom is 17, Shailkan thinks about their college education. In order to have additional savings, the family initiated a small business of goat breeding. Three years of hard work have brought its fruits. The family was blessed to build a big house. From now on, the family does its best to have a larger stock. For purchasing several more goats, Shailkan applied for a loan from Kiva. She is sure of repaying the loan on time with no violation. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase goats

loans.name: Gulzamira's Group

texts.en:
Women are vulnerable members of community. In Kyrgyzstan their rights are well-guarded by NGOs and legal foundations. But every woman has a special strength inside--a mother instinct, when a child can become an iron stimulus for overcoming all life's hardships. Gulzamira is a happy mother of three children and has a special story to tell.

Gulzamira J., 41, is the leader of this group. She’s been running a clothing sales business in a market in a small town called Tashkomur. While Gulzamira is at work, her three children have to wait for their mother to come home in the evenings. She sells retail while buying wholesale goods imported from China. 

Gulzamira is a very skilled saleswoman; she knows how to find an individual approach to every customer and always ends up persuading them to buy something more. She does a lot to attract as many customers as possible, because the competition is strong. She is very concerned with the types of clothing she has, therefore she tries to follow customers’ tastes, styles, and pricing preferences. With this loan she wants to buy winter clothing of a variable assortment. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase winter clothing

loans.name: Thamer

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 22 years old and a married man.

Thamer has a long experience in baking; in 2006 he decided to open his own bakery. The business is located in a populated area. He is becoming well know and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate the bakery, installing an external ceiling and shutters. He is planning to expand his business and increase his revenue.

loans.use: Renovate the bakery, install an external ceiling and shutters

loans.name: Hakem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 55 years old, married, and has 6 children.

Hakem opened his own business in 2003. He provides chairs and tables for weddings and all kind of events. The business is becoming well known in his local area, and he has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2400 loan to renovate his shop and install shutters. He is planning to extend his business and increase his revenue.

loans.use: Renovate his shop and install shutters

loans.name: Zarrina

texts.en:
Zarrina is married with three children. She lives and works in Khujand, selling women’s clothing in the central marketplace. Zarrina launched her small venture 8 years ago and has gained much experience and a loyal clientele in the meanwhile. Zarrina is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to increase her working capital. She hopes to continue developing her business and improving her living standards. Zarrina has proved to be a reliable and solvent client.

loans.use: Increasing working capital to develop her business

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua A. sells 'kenkey' (balls of fermented maize dough) at Abura.  Ekua has received junior high education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a mason. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy additional maize to prepare 'kenkey' for distribution. She hopes to buy a plot of land from her profit.

At the time of this visit, the maize to be used for the 'kenkey' was not ready. She is showing the soaked maize to be used for the 'kenkey'.

loans.use: to buy additional maize to prepare 'kenkey' for distribution

loans.name: Abdullojon

texts.en:
Abdullojon is married with three children. He owns a small business that sells foodstuffs in bulk. His business is located at the market and many retail vendors get their goods from Abdullojon. Low prices and good customer service help him to keep repeat customers. Abdullojon has been in this business for 5 years. This is the only income for this family. 

Abdullojon would like to borrow 1500 USD to increase his assortment. Abdullojon is a talented entrepreneur and wants to develop his business even further.

loans.use: Purchasing more foodstuffs to expand his range of goods

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena K. displays fruit, drinks, sugar, groundnuts and other items on a table for sale at Abura.  She has received senior high education.  She is married and has one child. Her husband is a pastor. Abena has been in this business for three years. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to expand her business. She hopes to build a shop with the new profit.

loans.use: to expand her food selling business

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. produces 'kenkey' (balls of fermented maize dough) at Abura for sale. Efua has been through senior high education.  She is married and has ten dependents. Her husband is a farmer. Efua has been selling 'kenkey' for ten years. She assists her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to expand her 'kenkey' business. She hopes to educate her dependents with the additional income.

In front of her is a bowl of the dough to be molded into 'kenkey' balls. In her hand what the 'kenkey' looks like when a ball of it is wrapped in banana leaf.

loans.use: to expand her 'kenkey' business

loans.name: Anvarjon

texts.en:
Anvarjon is very demanding in his work, having been a farmer since he was young. Today, as a head of household, he works tirelessly to generate a stable income. He works caring for his animals, getting up very early to gather grass so he can keep his livestock well-fed. Anvarjon sells the milk they produce, as well as the grasses that he cultivates on his land. He is seeking this current loan for the purchase of calves to expand his business. 

Anvarjon is sincerely grateful for your support. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: 43 years old M. Stephen has been selling bananas in Kyanyamuromba food market, Ibanda for the past decade. It is a business the happily married father of four says he began with savings from a crude alcohol sells business. Earnings from this business have in a way enabled him to shoulder some of his family's responsibilities, although by and large, he says he still faces long financial odds especially on the issue of expanding his business. He says his wife is always at his beck and call. Monthly he says this business generates him shillings 250,000 and with this loan he says he is going to purchase farm agricultural inputs.

loans.use: The purchase of farm agricultural inputs

loans.name: Meena

texts.en: Meena A. is married and has one child. Her husband is a palm wine tapper.  Meena sells palm oil and palm kernel oil at Abura. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. The loan she hopes to get will be used to buy more kernels to process for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Meena plans to buy a nut-cracking machine.

loans.use: to buy more kernels to process for sale

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba E. sells second-hand clothing at Abura. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a security man. Aba has been selling second-hand clothing for four years. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to expand her second-hand clothing business

loans.name: Boshi

texts.en:
N. Boshi is 60 years old. He is married with 4 children. For more than 20 years, Boshi has arduously dedicated himself to the livestock business. When he recognized the need to invest in his work, Boshi decided to construct a place to start the business of animal breeding. He started only with two sheep but now he has about 10 sheep. Now Boshi wants to expand his business and to buy more sheep. 

Trustingly he has sought IMON, believing that his loan request will be granted and with this he will be able to move forward in his work. Your support will really help to Boshi and his family to get ahead.        

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young livestock

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua M. sells 'kenkey' (balls of fermented maize dough) at Abura.  Ekua has received senior high education.  She is divorced and takes care of three children. She sees to the well-being of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to cook for sale. She plants to invest her profit into her children’s education. 

She is in the process of preparing the 'kenkey' in this photo.

loans.use: to buy more maize to cook for sale

loans.name: Akil

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 31 years old. He is married and has 5 children.

Akil has a good experience in commerce. He owns a food market. He is becoming well known in the market and has a good reputation.

He is requesting $3000 to renovate his store and expand the inventory. He is aiming to grow his shop so it is bigger in the future. This will help him to improve his quality of life.

loans.use: Renovate his store and expand the inventory

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. She sells charcoal in both smaller and larger quantity at Abura. Esi uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Esi will use the loan to purchase additional charcoal for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional charcoal for sale

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua M. is a divorced woman, who takes care of seven dependants. To earn a living, Ekua fries fish, which she sells in Abura. Ekua uses her business income to support her dependants.

Ekua is seeking a loan in the amount of $350 to purchase additional fish, which she would then fry and sell to her customers. Ekua plans to reinvest the expected increase in profits generated as a result of this loan back into her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional fish

loans.name: Hamid

texts.en:
Hamid is 64 years old, married and a father of five children.

He has a long experience in the trade business so he opened his mini-market. Hamid has gained a good reputation throughout the years in his business and is well known in his area.

He requested a $2,400 loan to set up a proper window for his store and buy more inventories. He aims to expand his business by providing a larger variety of products and eventually increase his income in the long run.

loans.use: To set up a proper window for his store and buy more inventories

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua A. is a married woman. To earn a living, she works as a baker in Abura. She has been in this trade for ten years. Ekua uses her business income to take care of herself and her family.

Ekua is requesting a loan in the amount of $275 to purchase baking ingredients so that she can bake on a larger scale. With the expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan and from an expanded business, Ekua plans to buy an additional oven.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional baking ingredients

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame E. is a married woman, who was educated through the junior high school level. Her husband is a mason. To earn a living, she sells cooked rice, eggs, canned tomatoes, and other food items in Abura. By doing so, she is able to assist her husband pay their utility bills and their children's school fees.

She is now seeking a loan in the amount of $225 to expand her business. She hopes to use the expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan to build a shop.

loans.use: To expand her cooking business and to ultimately build her own store

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old and married. He lives with seven family members. Only two of them work.

In 2008, Ali decided to start his own business by opening a food market in a residential area. He is becoming well known in his local community and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $3,000 loan to buy a big generator, pay the rent and increase his inventory. He is planning to expand his business to have more customers.

loans.use: To buy a generator, pay the rent and increase his inventory.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua B. is a married woman, who was educated through the junior high school level. Her husband is a carpenter. To earn a living, Ekua prepares kenkey in Abura. (In the picture, she is in the process of mixing the dough, which will then be made into kenkey.) By doing so, she is able to assist her husband take care of their home and support their family.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $225 to buy more maize so that she can produce kenkey in larger quantities. She hopes to use the expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan to buy land.

loans.use: To expand her business and to increase production by purchasing additional maize

loans.name: Araba

texts.en:
Araba A. is a married woman, who has been educated through senior high school. She is married to a farmer. To earn a living, she sells charcoal and smoked fish in Abura. (In the picture, she is shown with some fresh fish that she is about to smoke.) By doing so, she is able to assist her husband in taking care of their family.

She is now seeking a loan in the amount of $225 to expand her fish business. She anticipates reinvesting the expected additional income generated as a result of the loan back into her business to further expand the business.

loans.use: To expand her fish- and charcoal-selling business

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is a 27-year-old married man.

In 2007, Mohamad decided to open his own carpentry shop since he is well experienced in this field. He is becoming well known and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a $2,400 loan to buy a big machine related to his business. He is aiming to grow bigger and improve his work.

loans.use: To buy a big machine related to his business

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua N. is a married woman, who sells maize and groundnuts that have been prepared together for consumption in Abura. More specifically, the maize and groundnuts are wrapped together in a corn husk and then boiled. (She is pictured with groundnuts and maize to be wrapped with the corn husk.) The end product is normally eaten in the early hours of the morning. She explains that she has been in this business for seven years. Her husband is a farmer. With her business income, she is able to assist her husband take care of their home.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $225 to purchase additional maize and groundnuts to then be cooked for sale to her customers. She plans to reinvest expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan back into her business.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional ingredients

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua D. sells provisions and kitchen utensils at Abura. Ekua has completed her education through junior high school. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a blacksmith. She assists her husband in order to educate her children. Her customers are asking for other types of utensils. She is requesting to use the loan to acquire other types of utensils to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the business.

loans.use: To acquire kitchen utensils to sell

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Roseline D.. She is married and has two children, ages 7 and 10. In 2007, Roseline established her gara cloth business. She began her business in order to help her husband pay expenses for educating the children and building a house. Working six days a week and six hours a day, she earns about 400,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL. Roseline  requires a loan in order to buy more raw materials: brillian cloth (10 pieces @ 120,000 SLL), tie-dye ink (100 pkts. @ 4,000 SLL), gara powder (200 pkts. @ 1,500 SLL), and caustic soda (50 pkts @ 1,000 SLL). She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 500,000 SLL. In the future, Roseline D. plans to open a bigger shop in the city of Sierra Leone and hire workers or salespersons. She is very determined. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make gara cloth

loans.name: Aba Ama

texts.en: Aba Ama T. prepares Fante kenkey (boiled maize dough) at Abura for sale. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a farmer. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy extra bags of maize to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to provide a meaningful education for her children. In the photo above, Aba is in the process of wrapping the dough to make the kenkey.

loans.use: To buy maize

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es:
La Sra. Rosa Argentina C. T., es madre soltera de cinco hijos de los cuales solo dos tiene a su  cargo actualmente se dedica a la venta de atoles y pan la cual las realiza ambulante en las calles de la ciudad León, cabe mencionar que lleva 11 años dedicados a esta labor, lo que ha venido ayudarle a mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su familia.
Con los créditos que Ceprodel  le ha brindado ella compra al por mayor el producto tales como: leña rolliza, leña rajada, azúcar, y ron para elaboración de atoles y así  ha logrado ha logrado a incrementar su capital lo cual le ha ayudado realizar  mejora a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rosa Argentina C. T. is a single mother with five children, two of whom still live with her.  She sells bread and atole, a popular hot maize-based drink, throughout the city of León.  She has been doing this for 11 years, which has helped her improve the living conditions for her and her family.

With the loans Ceprodel has given her, she bought wholesale products like firewood, cut firewood, sugar, and rum for making atole.  Doing so has increased her revenue, which has helped her improve her home.

loans.use: Buying firewood, sugar, rum

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace A. is a widow taking care of three children. She has been through senior high school.  Grace has been cooking food for sale at Abura for some time using her income for the well-being of her family and home. She will use the loan to purchase food items to cook for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Grace plans to build a cafeteria.

loans.use: to purchase food items to cook for sale

loans.name: Milton

texts.en: B. Milton, 53, began selling cattle 20 years ago in Katoto-Ibanda. Before that, this reserved and down-to- earth married father of five sold agricultural produce. His determination, his friends say has gotten him this far and explains his longevity in a business which is highly competitive in western Uganda where many people own cattle. Milton ekes out additional profits from selling goats. Monthly this business generates 500,000 shillings for Milton and with this loan, he will buy more cattle to resell

loans.use: The purchase of cattle to resell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena Ammissah sells charcoal at Abura. She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a carpenter. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy additional bags of charcoal for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy additional bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old and lives with one of his family members.

In 2009, Ahmad opened a small food market since he has a good experience in this field. Now he is well know in his local area and has a good reputation.

He is requesting $1,800 to renovate his shop. He is planning to extend his business and increase his revenues.

loans.use: To renovate his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy corrugated metal roofing, roofing beams, anti-rust paint and bolts

loans.name: Cesar Willian

texts.es:
Cesar Willian M. C. tiene 37 años de edad. Es casado Vive con la esposa y junto a sus hijos en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los ríos. Tiene dos hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. JESUS NOS AMA se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto los Amarillos, Perteneciente al Cantón Ventanas Esta Ventanilla se dedica a labores Agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz, esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Cesar Willian se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, arroz, cacao desde hace 5 años. Compra sus productos en Agripac Eicopa, y  vende en la feria en Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz, arroz, Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es tener un cultivo de cacao.

Le gusta practicar el deporte.
texts.en:
Cesar Willian M. C., aged 37, is married and lives with his wife and their children in the canton of Ventanas in the province of Los Ríos. He has two children.

The members of the rural communal bank "Jesús Nos Ama" (Jesus loves us) meet on the grounds of Amarillos in the canton of Ventanas. This group works in agriculture in short-cycle sowing of corn and rice. Its members have been in this activity for a long time.

Cesar Willian is a farmer. He has grown corn, rice and cocoa for 5 years. He buys his agricultural supplies from Agripac Eicopa and sells his products at the market in Ventanas.

He applies for a loan to buy agricultural consumables and fertilizers that he needs to grow corn and rice. The loan will help him to pay for the required supplies. He faces challenges such as plagues, diseases and weather changes. His dream is to own a field to grow cocoa. He likes doing sport.

loans.use: To buy agricultural consumables and fertilizers

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi F. is divorced and takes care of five dependants. She sells bags of charcoal at Abura using her income to feed, clothe, and educate her dependants. Esi will use the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to distribute to her growing number of customers and plans to reinvest her profit in the business.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. is divorced and has three children. She sells yam tubers at Abura using the income she makes for the general upkeep of her home. The loan will be used to purchase extra yam tubers for sale. With the profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase yam tubers for sale

loans.name: Erwin Daniel

texts.es:
Erwin Daniel V. M. Es soltero Vive con los padres En el cantón Ventanas provincia de los ríos. No tiene hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. JESUS NOS AMA se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto los Amarillos, Perteneciente al Cantón Ventanas Esta Ventanilla se dedica a labores Agrícolas de ciclo corto siembra de maíz, arroz, esta actividad llevan mucho tiempo haciéndolo.

Erwin Daniel se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, arroz, cacao desde hace 5 años. Compra sus productos en Agripac Eicopa, y  vende en la feria en Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas y fertilizantes para el cultivo de maíz, arroz, Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es culminar sus estudios, comprarse una casa y una finca.

Le gusta practicar el deporte.
texts.en:
Erwin Daniel V. M. is single and lives with his parents in Ventanas canton, in Los Rios province.  He doesn't have any children.

The JESUS NOS AMA community bank is located in Los Amarillos neighborhood, in Ventanas canton.  The members of this community bank work in short-cycle agriculture, growing corn and rice.  They have been in this line of work for a long time.

Erwin Daniel is a farmer who has been growing corn, rice and cacao for 5 years.  He buys his products in Agripac Eicopa and sells his products in Ventanas market.

Erwin Daniel is requesting this loan to buy agricultural supplies and fertilizers for his corn and rice crops.  The support of this loan will help him to financially cover his needs.
